summary.title: Assignment2
summary.description:
The assignment of  SENG406 is  about a Dog register web app. A web-based application designed to register dogs in order to get their identification tags, as well as the management and traceability of dogs. Owners can register their dogs, and receive or renew their unique tags delivered by the Council. Dogs can be declared lost or found, and owners can terminate a registration before its expiration date.

The app, as we define it, exposes the following (simplified) features:
  * individuals can register their dog to the app and order dog tags.
  * individuals can renew their dog tags and get the new dog tags.
  * the council delivers the dogs tags to  the user.
  * member of the public can report potential lost dogs.
  * the council picks up the lost dog and notifies the dog owner. 

End-user app
  * Does not store private details, i.e. contact details, address, and bank / PayPal account (stored in private database)
  * Registers a dog
  * Renew a registration
  * Terminate a registration
  * Declare a lost dog
  * Report of found dog

Trust levels (privileges):
  1  Anonymous user
  2  Dog owner
  3  Database Administrator
  4  Website Administrator
  5  Email process
  6  Banking process
  7  Dog pickup service
  8  Dog tag manufacturing process
  9  Database Read User
  10 Database Read/Write User
  11 Web server User Process

diagrams.title: Original system

data.name:
Register 
a dog
data.description: Action to register a dog.

threats.title: Fake personal information
threats.description: A dog owner could use fake personal information, such as name and physical address, when registering a dog. They would then be able to deny affiliation with the dog.

threats.title: Flooding of requests from the same IP
threats.description: User trying to register large numbers of dogs at the same time.
threats.mitigation:
* Add a cooldown time for the same IP to register another dog
* Implement rate limiting to restrict the number of requests a single IP address can make
* Use CAPTCHA on the registration form to prevent automated bots

threats.title: User claims to have made payment
threats.description: The user falsely claims they have paid the registration fee (denies not paying).
threats.mitigation:
* Keep a copy of bank receipts, including the registration number reference and timestamps
* Use digital signatures for payment receipts and invoices
* Integrate an automated payment gateway that verifies the payments in real-time

threats.title: Adversary in the middle changes the registration details
threats.description: An adversary-in-the-middle intercepts the registration and modifies its content (e.g., email address and physical address)
threats.mitigation:
* Use secure connection, http-only and secure cookie with unique session id
* Sign (hash) content with user's private key

threats.title: Adversary-in-the-middle gain information
threats.description: An adversary-in-the-middle intercepts the data and reads sensitive information.
threats.mitigation:
* Protect data using TLS
* Isolate the communication channels used for transmitting sensitive data
* Implement secure communication channels

threats.title: Insecure connection
threats.description: Data can be tampered by an adversary in the middle where the information can be modified.
threats.mitigation:
* Use TLS to encrypt the data in transit
* Implement hashing to create a checksum of the data before transmission and verify it upon receipt
* Enforce HTTPS by implementing HSTS, which instructs browsers to only interact with the server over a secure HTTPS connection

data.name: Dog datastore
data.description: This database contains the details of the dogs, including their name, breed, status, registration number, expiry date, tag ID, and owner.

threats.title: Unauthorised modification of dog data
threats.description: An attacker might gain unauthorised access and alter the information of the dog (e.g., name, lost status, owner, dog tag ID).
threats.mitigation:
* Utilise hashing and checksum mechanisms to detect and prevent unauthorised changes to data
* Implement role based access controls to restrict database write permissions to authorised personnel only
* Regular audits and integrity checks on the database to identify any unauthorised changes

threats.title: Dog datastore unwanted access
threats.description: Sensitive information might be exposed to unauthorised individuals.
threats.mitigation:
* Datastore credentials are securely stored on password vaults with limited set of users having access (apply least privilege principle).
* Datastore credentials are injected into connecting software from secured variables or files (apply least privilege principle).

threats.title: Disputed data changes
threats.description: An attacker or insider could dispute or deny making changes to records within the datastore, leading to challenges in auditing and accountability.
threats.mitigation:
* Maintain detailed, tamper-evident logs of all actions performed on the datastore, including timestamps, user IDs, and specific changes
* Use cryptographic signatures on logs
* Restrict access to the datastore and its logs, allowing only authorised personnel to make changes

data.name:
Dog owner 
datastore
data.description: This database contains all dog owner data, including their pronoun, first and last name, email address, and physical address.

threats.title: Unauthorised modification of dog owner data
threats.description: An attacker might gain unauthorised access and alter the information of the dog owner (e.g., name, email, etc)
threats.mitigation:
* Utilise hashing and checksum mechanisms to detect and prevent unauthorised changes to data
* Implement role based access controls to restrict database write permissions to authorised personnel only
* Regular audits and integrity checks on the database to identify any unauthorised changes

threats.title: Dog owner datastore unwanted access
threats.description: Sensitive information might be exposed to unauthorised individuals.
threats.mitigation:
* Datastore credentials are securely stored on password vaults with limited set of users having access (apply least privilege principle).
* Datastore credentials are injected into connecting software from secured variables or files (apply least privilege principle).

threats.title: Disputed data changes
threats.description: An attacker or insider could dispute or deny making changes to records within the datastore, leading to challenges in auditing and accountability.
threats.mitigation:
* Maintain detailed, tamper-evident logs of all actions performed on the datastore, including timestamps, user IDs, and specific changes
* Use cryptographic signatures on logs
* Restrict access to the datastore and its logs, allowing only authorised personnel to make changes

data.name: Send email
data.description: Allows the system to send emails to the dog owner.

threats.title: Fake emails
threats.description: Attackers could send fake emails to the dog owners, leading to confusion and potential security breaches.
threats.mitigation:
* Include specific information in the email that only the council would know (e.g., registration number)
* Use domain-based email authentication protocols like SPF, DKIM, and DMARC
* Include warnings in legitimate emails about phishing threats and provide a secure method for users to report suspicious emails
* Only include secure links with HTTPS

data.name:
Pay 
registration 
fee
data.description: Allows the dog owner to pay for the dog registration.
data.reasonOutOfScope: Not in control of the application. because the application is not providing any payment method.

data.name:
Manufacture and
 send new tag
data.description: Manufactures and sends the new dog tag with the new dog tag ID to the dog owner's physical address.

threats.title: Owner denies receiving tag
threats.description: The tag owner may deny having received the tag.
threats.mitigation:
* Logging steps in the manufacturing process, such as completion date
* Tracking the package when sending to the owner

data.name:
Renew dog 
registration
data.description: Action to renew an existing dog registration.

threats.title: Impersonation of dog owner
threats.description: An attacker could repeatedly enter a tag ID, causing the system to spam the tag owner's email. Can lead to Denial of Service.

threats.title: User claims to have made payment
Adversary in the middle changes the renewal details
threats.description: An adversary-in-the-middle intercepts the registration renewal details and modifies its content (e.g., address to deliver the new tag to)
threats.mitigation:
* Use secure connection, http-only and secure cookie with unique session id
* Sign (hash) content with user's private key

threats.title: Overload request
threats.description: Attackers could overload the process by sending a large number of fake or malicious requests.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement rate limiting to prevent DoS attacks
* Ensure that backups are available to restore normal operations quickly
* Monitor for unusual spikes in traffic and automatically block suspicious activity

data.name:
Terminate a
 registration
data.description: Action to terminate an existing dog registration.

threats.title: Fraudulent reporting
threats.description: A user could obtain another user's email address, dog ID, and dog name, and fraudulently terminate the dog's registration.

threats.title: Deny terminating registration
threats.description: A user could claim that somebody else impersonated them and terminated the dog's registration
threats.mitigation:
* Trace (log) session id, timestamp, originating IP and user id in log.
* Validate hashed checksum with end-user's public key.
* Send confirmation email (with email log).

threats.title: Flooding of requests from the same IP
threats.description: Multiple requests coming from the same IP, or multiple requests to terminate the same dog registration.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement rate limiting to restrict the number of requests that can be processed from the same IP address
* Add CAPTCHA to the termination request form to prevent automated bots

data.name:
Declare lost 
dog
data.description: Action to report a lost dog

threats.title: Fraudulent reporting
threats.description: Attackers may impersonate the dog owner if they know their email address and the dog's name. This can lead to false reports and the attacker also gains the dog’s most recent tag ID.

threats.title: Malformed data
threats.description: Attackers could pass through specially crafted malformed data, which can lead to denial of service or information disclosure.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement strong input validation and handle unexpected data types
* Ensure that a backup mechanism is in place to quickly restore service 
* Monitor data submissions for signs of DoS attempts in malformed data

threats.title: Overload request
threats.description: Attackers could overload the process by sending a large number of fake or malicious requests, leading to a denial of service that prevents legitimate users from reporting lost dogs.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement rate limiting to prevent DoS attacks
* Ensure that backups are available to restore normal operations quickly
* Monitor for unusual spikes in traffic and automatically block suspicious activity

threats.title: Denial of lost dog report
threats.description: Dog owner might later deny having made the lost dog report.
threats.mitigation:
* Send a confirmation email to the email address upon report process completion
* Maintain robust and secure logs of all transactions on the app
* Provide confirmation page when the report process has been completed

data.name:
Report found 
dog
data.description: Action to report a found dog.

threats.title: False reports
threats.description: Anonymous users can get access to the dogs tag number and report the dog as found or report the dog at false locations.
threats.mitigation: * Use the dog status to find out the dogs, if the owner reported it as LOST. If the status is anything other than LOST don't do anything.

threats.title: Adversary-in-the-Middle - changes the dog tags
threats.description: An attacker getting access to the network can change the dog tags.
threats.mitigation:
*  Validate legitimate dog tags 
*  Encrypt the information while the data is in transit

threats.title: Deny reporting
threats.description: An attacker can deny they did not report any dogs.

threats.title: Endpoint Denial of Service - either with one IP of distributed IPs
threats.description: An attacker may report multiple times with the same IP or bot net distributed network to prevent valid reports.
threats.mitigation:
* IP white list and  black listing.
* Anti DDoS attack services i.e. cloudflare.
* Filter Network Traffic using services provided by Content Delivery Networks (CDN).

data.name:
Member of 
the public
data.description: Anonymous member of the public.

data.name:
Pick up 
found dog
data.description: Dog services that are responsible of collecting lost dogs.

cells.description: A person living in the jurisdiction of the Council who owns one or more dogs.

Full name,
Street Address,
Postal Address
Email,
Dog name,
Dog breed

data.name:
Register 
a dog
data.description: Action to register a dog.

threats.title: Register a dog under someone else's name
threats.description: A dog owner (whether they have an account or not) could try to register a dog under someone else's name. They would then be able to deny affiliation with the dog.
threats.mitigation:
*  Principle of least privilege - only allow logged in users to register their own dogs
* Use session IDs to identify logged in users

threats.title: Flooding of requests from the same IP
threats.description: User trying to register large numbers of dogs at the same time.
threats.mitigation:
* Add a cooldown time for the same IP to register another dog
* Implement rate limiting to restrict the number of requests a single IP address can make
* Use CAPTCHA on the registration form to prevent automated bots

threats.title: User claims to have made payment
threats.description: The user falsely claims they have paid the registration fee (denies not paying).
threats.mitigation:
* Keep a copy of bank receipts, including the registration number reference and timestamps
* Use digital signatures for payment receipts and invoices
* Integrate an automated payment gateway that verifies the payments in real-time

threats.title: Adversary in the middle changes the registration details
threats.description: An adversary-in-the-middle intercepts the registration and modifies its content (e.g., email address and physical address)
threats.mitigation:
* Use secure connection, http-only and secure cookie with unique session id
* Sign (hash) content with user's private key

data.name: Dog Owner
data.description: A person living in the jurisdiction of the Council who owns one or more dogs.

threats.title: Weak password
threats.mitigation: * Require passwords to be at least 8 characters long and include at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, one number, and one special character.

threats.title: Attempt to renew someone else's dog registration

threats.mitigation:
* Principle of least privilege - only allow users to renew their own dogs' registrations
* Use session IDs to keep track of logged in users

* Sign (hash) content with user's private key

threats.title: Overload request
threats.description: Attackers could overload the process by sending a large number of fake or malicious requests.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement rate limiting to prevent DoS attacks
* Ensure that backups are available to restore normal operations quickly
* Monitor for unusual spikes in traffic and automatically block suspicious activity

data.name:
Terminate a
 registration
data.description: Action to terminate an existing dog registration.

threats.title: Terminate some else's dog registration
threats.description: A user could terminate the dog registration that is owned by someone else.
threats.mitigation:
* Principle of least privilege - only allow the dog's owner to terminate the registration. 
* Give a unique session id when logging in to check the identity of the user.

threats.title: Deny terminating registration
threats.description: A user could claim that somebody else impersonated them and terminated the dog's registration
threats.mitigation:
* Trace (log) session id, timestamp, originating IP and user id in log.
* Validate hashed checksum with end-user's public key.
* Send confirmation email (with email log).

threats.title: Flooding of requests from the same IP
threats.description: Multiple requests coming from the same IP, or multiple requests to terminate the same dog registration.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement rate limiting to restrict the number of requests that can be processed from the same IP address
* Add CAPTCHA to the termination request form to prevent automated bots

data.name:
Declare lost 
dog
data.description: Action to report a lost dog

threats.title: Report some else's dog as lost
threats.description: Attackers may try to declare someone else's dog as lost.
threats.mitigation:
* Principle of least privilege - only allow users to declare their own dogs as lost
* Use session IDs to keep track of logged in users

threats.title: Malformed data
threats.description: Attackers could pass through specially crafted malformed data, which can lead to denial of service or information disclosure.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement strong input validation and handle unexpected data types
* Ensure that a backup mechanism is in place to quickly restore service 
* Monitor data submissions for signs of DoS attempts in malformed data

threats.title: Overload request
threats.description: Attackers could overload the process by sending a large number of fake or malicious requests, leading to a denial of service that prevents legitimate users from reporting lost dogs.
threats.mitigation:
* Implement rate limiting to prevent DoS attacks
* Ensure that backups are available to restore normal operations quickly
* Monitor for unusual spikes in traffic and automatically block suspicious activity

threats.title: Denial of lost dog report
threats.description: Dog owner might later deny having made the lost dog report.
threats.mitigation:
* Send a confirmation email to the email address upon report process completion
* Maintain robust and secure logs of all transactions on the app
* Provide confirmation page when the report process has been completed

data.name:
Report found 
dog
data.description: Action to report a found dog.

threats.title: False reports
threats.description: Anonymous users can get access to the dogs tag number and report the dog as found or report the dog at false locations.
threats.mitigation:
* Check the dog's current status - if the owner reported it as LOST, then send the dog services. If the status is anything other than LOST, email the dog owner to confirm whether the dog is actually lost. 
* Require all reports to include an image of the found dog's tag, which is then manually checked by a council member.
* Flag email accounts that are used for multiple false reports and ignore future reports from them.

threats.title: Adversary-in-the-Middle - changes the dog tags
threats.description: An attacker getting access to the network can change the dog tags.
threats.mitigation:
*  Validate legitimate dog tags 
*  Encrypt the information while the data is in transit

threats.title: Deny reporting
threats.description: An attacker can deny they reported any dogs.
threats.mitigation:
* Require all reports to be confirmed by emailing the reporter a verification link
* Keep a log of the email used for each report

threats.title: Endpoint Denial of Service - either with one IP of distributed IPs
threats.description: An attacker may report multiple times with the same IP or bot net distributed network to prevent valid reports.
threats.mitigation:
* IP white list and  black listing.
* Anti DDoS attack services i.e. cloudflare.
* Filter Network Traffic using services provided by Content Delivery Networks (CDN).

data.name:
Member of 
the public
data.description: Anonymous member of the public.

data.name:
Pick up 
found dog
data.description: Dog services that are responsible of collecting lost dogs.

data.name:
Account 
registration
data.description: Action to register as a dog owner.

threats.title: Register an account as someone else
threats.description: A user could register an account as someone else.
threats.mitigation: * Require users to click a unique link (which is sent via email) to finish registering.

threats.title: Flooding of requests from the same IP
threats.description: A user trying to register large numbers of owner accounts at the same time.
threats.mitigation:
* Add a cooldown time for the same IP to register another dog
* Implement rate limiting to restrict the number of requests a single IP address can make
* Use CAPTCHA on the registration form to prevent automated bots

data.name: Login
data.description: Action for a dog owner to log in.

threats.title: Logging in as someone else
threats.description: A user could try to log in with stolen credentials, or brute-force the password.
threats.mitigation:
* Require two-factor email authentication whenever a user logs in from a new browser.  
* After 5 consecutive incorrect guesses, lock the account for 30 seconds.

threats.title: Multiple automated requests
threats.description: Automated tools could send large amounts of requests to the site to slow down or crash the system.
threats.mitigation:
* Use CAPTCHA challenges to confirm that the user is human
* Add time-outs for IPs that send too many requests at the same time

cells.description: A person living in the jurisdiction of the Council who owns one or more dogs.

Full name,
Street Address,
Postal Address
Email,
Dog name,
Dog breed
